I think of Bitcoin as an unbreakable, honest reserve bank storing the world's best savings instrument. It charges on average 0.5% to 1.5%/yr to guarantee security (=tx fees). Users only pay if they move funds, which rewards long term holders.pic.twitter.com/Wo5HtW9qRC

Fun playing around with analogies: Bitcoin ~ crude oil (store of value ~ potential energy) Lightning ~ electricity (payments ~ kinetic energy)https://twitter.com/fluidvoice/status/943484700638744578 …
Crude oil, paraffin, gasoline = potential Joules Bitcoin, lightning, sidechained btc = proof of Joules spent.

Think of Bitcoin as an unbreakable clearance bank that charges between 0.5% and 1.5% per year in management fees - lower usage = lower fees, higher usage = higher fees. Model favors large balances that fund 2nd layer payment channels and occasionally settle on the main chain.pic.twitter.com/htzJF82zk4

Also worth noting that Bitcoin Core is not Bitcoin. There are half a dozen Bitcoin protocol implementations; Bitcoin Core just happens to have the most contributors.

Indeed, that's a fun side effect of all the forking. The original is just "Bitcoin" and there's a thousand "Bitcoin blahs." Which results in folks choosing slang terms for the forks in order to disambiguate.
Bitcoin Core is a software implementation of the Bitcoin protocol. Perhaps you mean Bitcoin, the network?
You can compare the activity on the github repositories; the ones with the most activity are Bitcoin Core and Bitcoin ABC.
